reviewText: This movie sounded promising.  We love Christmas movies and really like the ones that are not all about Santa - which are very hard to find.  This movie sounded much like the plot of Comfort and Joy, Family Man, and Snowglobe.  We like those movies although we do find Snowglobe a bit cheesy but it's award winning compared to Holiday Switch.  This woman is perpetually mad at her husband who seems to be trying to make the best of everything even during the hard times but she doesn't care.  Then we're suppose to believe that a woman would actually crawl into her dryer!  She crawls into a life with a husband who is cheating on her and mad at her all the time (maybe if she had married him, he wouldn't have turned out that way but then with her attitude, I can see how he would have). It does switch around a lot as one reviewer noted and it's very hard to keep up with but then it's very hard to hold your interest. We donated this movie.  Don't waste your money.  Maybe we should all try climbing into our dryer if we want to see what our life might have been like if we had chosen a diferent path.

reviewText: Have you ever thought that your life could have been so much better if only you had taken a different turn at some point?Paula Ferguson runs into her old boyfriend at Christmas time. He's turned out to be a wealthy art dealer, living a life of luxury. At least that's the way it seems to the hard-working Paula, struggeling with debt, housework and family issues -- just like the rest of us. She makes a wish, and ends up transported into the alternate reality of her dreams. Of course, in the end, Paula would give just about anything to get back to her real world. But, this time, the wishing doesn't work!Holiday Switch was very cleverly done, and is a step above lots of other Christmas movies about dreams being granted.

reviewText: This is another new Christmas movie for us this year.  This was fun, funny, silly, and still had some serious moments that many people are facing--divorce, little money, bickering about the little things in life, wanting more "stuff" or the grass-is-greener-on-the-other-side feelings.It is a heartwarming movie, but not as predictable as most.  Again, around 85-90 minutes running time, so short enough to play without committing to a marathon of movie watching.  I did not recognize any of the actors in this, which makes it easier for me to watch sometimes because I'm not looking at the actor as much as the story.Like A Nanny for Christmas, this is very tame, but I would rate it PG only because very young kids might not enjoy it.  Also good for 8 years old and up, I'd say, but nothing too adult if there are young kids walking through the room--no profanity, no nudity, no politics, just a simple Christmas movie.  I'd say kind of a cross between It's a Wonderful Life and Cinderella.  Another fun movie for a slumber party for young preteens and teens.  Also a safe movie to show during family gatherings since most people have probably never seen it before.
summary: Two thumbs up for a Lifetime Christmas movie!
Title: N/A

reviewText: It's hard for me to believe that anyone disliked this film. I'm also not sure why at least one other reviewer had trouble following the story, as it is pretty straight-forward: Paula is dissatisfied with her life--particularly her husband and their financial woes. She runs into her former, financially successful boyfriend and thinks the grass would have been greener has she chosen to marry him instead. Paula's wish is granted, but she quickly discovers that money isn't everything and she should have appreciated what she had.My family and I really enjoyed this movie a lot. I would even go so far as to say I loved it. I checked it out of the library, but have been tempted to purchase it for my own DVD collection. Not only is it completely clean and family-friendly, but it was very entertaining and fun to watch. I was pleasantly surprised to note that my 6- and 4-year-old daughters also enjoyed it, although I think they were mostly enthralled by the "stuff" (ie, the jewels, clothes, etc).I admit it was fun to see all the rich-person stuff, but what particularly appealed to me was the basic moral of this tale: Be grateful for and appreciate the things you have, while you have them. It was a good reminder for me to stop dwelling on the negative and wishing for the things I think I want, and instead spend my time being grateful for my husband, my children, and my many, many blessings. Altogether a really great and uplifting family holiday movie. Highly recommend.

reviewText: This movie is about wishing for something that may be impossible to have because it may not turn out to be for the best.Nicole Eggert was awesome in this movie. She plays a woman named Paula, an aspiring artist, who along with her construction working husband, Gary, and two daughters, Eleanor and Olivia, are struggling to make ends meet. One day, she runs into an ex-boyfriend, Nick, who's married, and (unfortunately) [wealthy], and in the art gallery business. She actually does visit Nick's place.  Another day, Paula is in her basement, and unexpectedly hears voices coming through her washer/dryer. She peeks inside, and winds up bumping her head, then is out cold. Suddenly, she has a dream where she wonders what it would be like if she was married to Nick, and was [wealthy]. She hears the voices again through the washer/dryer, and crawls her way through it like she's in a magic tunnel, into Nick's house, and discovers that she's his wife. She then discovers that Nick is selfish, ungrateful, and unfaithful. She also discovers that Gary has been hired by Nick to set up a Christmas display, then discovers that he's married to a woman named Janine. Paula asks Gary if he remembers their time together. Gary says he does, but that's now history. Paula is in a real bind, and wishes for her old life back.  Eventually, at the Christmas party, Gary visits, and presents Paula with a gift. Paula is overjoyed. She and Gary kiss, then the dream fades, and she's back into her basement, and  comes to, so the wish of having her old life back comes true. Her family is supporting her. They go upstairs, and have a nice Christmas with family and friends. Gary even surprises Paula with a new gold Christmas ornament. So eventually, things are okay in the end (and financially too, I think). Paula then realizes she has a better life with Gary, than with Nick.This was a great movie. An interesting Christmas fantasy.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This movie is called Holiday Switch starring Nicole Eggert.  This movie is about a woman named Paula Ferguson who is a mother of two girls and a wife.  Its a week before Christmas and Paula is struggling with bills and trying to figure out what she should do for Christmas presents for her girls.  When Paula's old boyfriend from high school, Nick (Brett Le Bourveau)returns to town a wealthy art gallery owner.  Paula starts to wonder what would life be like if she chose Nick instead of Gary (Bret Anthony).  Paula magically transported through her washer/dryer to a parallel life where she is Nick's wife. Paula starts missing her husband, Gary and the girls.  Paula realizes that her life with Gary is pretty good and she would not want to change her life for anything.  Watch this movie to see if Paula never gets back to her old life with Gary and the girls! Enjoy!
summary: BE CAREFUL WHAT YOU WISH FOR!!!!!

reviewText: This is a really good movie. No swearing, but you do realize that the rich guy is a dog (and by that I mean lousy husband). If you watch with 8 or 9 year olds, you might have to explain that he is 'not a very nice man'. It will make anyone appreciate what they already have.  I really love all kinds of Christmas movies and old Christmas TV shows, so I will usually give them a high rating unless they are raunchy. I love Mr. Magoo's Christmas Carol (which brings me to tears when Jim Backus sings I'm All alone in the World). I Really love A Charlie Brown Christmas, and the Alvin and the Chipmunk Christmas show. Make sure it is the one where Alvin gives his harmonica away to a little sick boy.
summary: Review of Holiday Switch and reviews of some other good Christmas shows

reviewText: I almost gave it 4 stars because it's a little hokey the way the "Switch" happens. But, in reality it doesn't ruin the Movie at all! I still watch it every year without fail! The "message" in this movie is a good one for everyone anytime of year, while still being an entertaining holiday Movie! Basically it makes you appreciate what you have and that the grass isn't always greener on the other side of the fence, or dryer in this case! I really like Nicole Eggert in this movie alongside Bret Anthony (her real husband in the movie) and Brett Le Bourveau (her old flame, and husband in the switched life in the movie) great cast of characters! Patricia Mayen-Salazar is excellent and funny as the house keeper/friend. A Lite hearted yet touching Movie! Great for the whole family!!

reviewText: As I said in my (also embarrassing) review forChristmas Do-Over, I flat-out LOVE made-for-TV Christmas movies. For 11 months a year I have what I feel is fairly good taste in books, film and television, but for one month I throw that all aside an glut myself with holiday cheese ... Of the Hallmark movie variety. And admit I love every second of it.As the combined efforts of Hallmark, Liftetime, ION, etc. produce roughly 30 Christmas movies a seasons--I consider it a jobs program for former third-billed sitcom and drama stars; I mean, c'mon, Tori Spelling's kids gotta' eat!--using only about five pre-existing plots, there is definitely a formula to these cheaply-produced films. (We play an annual Christmas movie guessing game where one person says a real TV-movie title and the other has to guess the plot from that alone. After you see a handful of these types of films, you can get astoundingly good, very quickly.) One of my favorites are the christmas wish/alternate reality movies, of which HOLIDAY SWITCH is my all-time favorite.I mean, it's got a former BAYWATCH star crawling through her clothes DRYER (no, really) into an alternate life where she married the "one that got away" and leads a luxe upper-class existence, instead of her own, harried, cash-strapped reality. I mean, basically, it's almost a parody of itself already. And the films of this type that don't take themselves too seriously are always the most fun.Of course she learns the "true meaning of Christmas" and, one can only hope, also how to keep her lint trap cleaner in the future, but this movie really is a lot of fun and will certainly put you in the Christmas mood ... Which is the whole point. I'd also note it's a great introductory point for someone who isn't really all that keen on watching TV Christmas films.I will point out that, despite it's low price point, there's not much need to buy this DVD, as Lifetime will almost certainly air this movie many times during the Christmas season.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is one of my holiday favorites. I first saw this on Lifetime and watched it over and over so I thought I really need to buy this. In a nutshell the main character is unhappy with her ordinary wife/mother life. She is married with two daughters and they are struggling to make ends meet but her husband does what he can to provide for her and the girls. She runs into an old flame who is still  handsome and perfect and now rich and successful. He invites her to his gallery opening and after spending a little time with him wonders if she chose the right man to marry and life to live. Long story short she is in the basement doing chores ends up bumping her head and gets a chance to take a glimpse on the greener side so to speak. In this life she chooses the artsy fartsy rich guy who showers her with any and everthing but she is miserable and their marriage is falling apart. So she realizes that her life with her family may have been tough but she was loved and not lonely. Great holiday story with a great message!
